q.l: Mark it, Ceſario, it is true and plain;
The ſpinſters and the knitters in the ſun
And the free maids that weave their thread with bones,
Do uſe to chant it. It is ſilly, ſooth,
And dallies with the innocence of love,

div.p: LONDON: PRINTED FOR T. CADELL, IN THE STRAND. MDCCLXXXII.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT, By the EDITOR.
div.p:
THE young Lady who is the writer of the following Poem is a native of London, but was removed, with her Family, in very early life, to a remote part of the kingdom, where her ſole inſtruction was derived from a virtuous, amiable, and ſenſible mother. In ſo diſtant a ſituation, ſhe had ſuch little acceſs to books, that, when the piece now preſented to the public was written, ſhe had not read Mr. Cartwright's Armine and
Elvira, Dr. Percy's Hermit of Warkworth, and other beautiful productions of that kind. On her return to the metropolis laſt ſummer, the Poem being ſhewn to ſeveral of her acquaintance, they earneſtly requeſted its publication; to which ſhe hath conſented, with the modeſty and diffidence that, in the ſeaſon of youth, are the uſual concomitants of true virtue. Having long been intimate with the family, I with pleaſure undertook the taſk of Editor; and my pleaſure will be greatly increaſed, if this performance ſhall meet with a favourable reception from the judges of poetical merit. Should there be found in it many marks of an elegant and pathetic genius, to theſe not only the candid, but even the judicious critic will direct his principal attention; and will be diſpoſed to forgive the ſimplicity of the ſtory, and that
diffuſion of ſentiment which is ſo natural to a youthful mind, in its firſt eſſays in compoſition.

lg.l: WHERE the clear DERWENT'S waters glide
Cloſe by the river's verdant ſide,
The ancient pile by time eras'd,
Once many a ſculptur'd trophy grac'd,
There liv'd a Chief, to fame well known,
Who many a well-fought field had won
What time in martial pomp he led
The foe that erſt had conquer'd, fled,
And in his calm and yielding breaſt
Not all the rugged toils of war
He felt for every child of care,
His heart was apt to feel.
And much that heart was doom'd to bear,
And many a grief to prove;
To feel the fulneſs of deſpair,
To loſe the partner of his breaſt,
And with mild efforts charm'd to reſt
The griefs ſhe ſought to ſhare.
He mark'd the chilling damps of death
He ſaw her yield her quiv'ring breath,
And ſink in death's cold arms.
To cheriſh there his ſacred grief,
Here, object of his fondeſt cares,
And oft the mourner's falling tears
Theſe tears, as o'er the babe he hung,
While bleſſings fault'ring on his tongue,
Were breath'd but in a ſigh.
For many a ſad revolving year
For ah! a ſorrow ſo ſevere
Yet time can ſoften the deep wound
It has not power to heal;
And in this child he thought he found
Twas eaſy in her look to trace
There dwelt each mild attractive grace,
Soft as the dews of morn ariſe,
And on the pale flower gleam,
So ſoft, ſo ſweet her melting eyes
As far retir'd the lonely flower
And blows its balmy ſweets to pour
So ſweetly grac'd the vernal ſcene,
Yet love could pierce the lone receſs,
For there he loves to dwell;
He ſcorns the noiſy croud to bleſs,
In all its power is known;
His empire ſways each willing heart;
Firſt taught her heart to prove
That gentleſt paſſion of the breaſt,
To ſeel the power of love.
Tho' few the paſtures he poſſeſt,
Tho' wealth ne'er ſwell'd his hoarded cheſt,
EDWIN could boaſt the liberal mind,
The maxims of this ſervile age,
The ſordid views that now engage
Whom riches can unite or part,
They little knew that wealth had power
They little knew the ſplendid dower
Could add a bliſs to love.
They little knew the human breaſt
Or, of a faithful heart poſſeſt,
And tho' her peerleſs beauty warms
Not leſs he felt the laſting charms,
Not leſs his gentle ſoul approv'd
For ſurely Virtue to be lov'd
The ſweets of dear domeſtic bliſs
And meek-ey'd hope, and inward peace
Some lambkin to the fold to lead,
Her heart, where pity lov'd to dwell,
For the bruis'd inſect as it fell,
As roving o'er the flow'ry waſte,
A ſigh would heave her breaſt
The while her gentle hand replac'd
Then would ſhe ſeek the vernal bow'r,
To nurſe ſome pale declining flow'r,
And oft with eager ſteps ſhe flies
Where the poor widow pour her ſighs,
Their meek imploring look ſhe fees,
Wild throbs her aching boſom ſwell!
(Nature has form'd the ſoul to feel)
HER hands the lib'ral boon impart,
To ſooth the mourner's burſting heart,
On the pale cheek where hung the tear
She bids the guſh of joy riſe there,
Thus ſoft the gliding moments flew,
While ſome new virtue roſe to view,
Peace, long condemn'd the world to roam,
And wiſh'd no more to rove.
For Virtue, in this vale of tears,
But vainly here we hope that bliſs
Ah, in a world ſo vain as this,
For now aroſe the death-fraught day,
When YORK from LANCASTER's proud ſway,
The paſſing moments now were fraught
And now the bloody deeds were wrought
The good old ALBERT vows again
The cauſe of HENRY to maintain,
The ſpear for him to wield.
But oh, a thouſand ſacred ties
And link the youth to HENRY's foes—
But ah, it rends his heart
Tho' paſſion pleads in HENRY's cauſe,
Oppreſs'd with many a mingled care,
And mourn'd the rugged brow of war
At length the fatal morn aroſe
And pale fear heav'd her breaſt.
A thouſand pangs the father feels,
While at his feet ſhe trembling kneels,
And bathes them with her tears.
A falling drop bedew'd his cheek,
From the ſad ſcene he flew;
The tender father could not ſpeak—
And tremblings ſeize her tender frame,
" The heart it means to bleſs:
" Thoſe falling tears, thoſe plaintive ſounds,
" Then be to wretched EDWIN kind,
At length, on EDWIN's breaſt reclin'd,
" My EDWIN's deſtin'd heart to bleed,
" And ſwell the heaps of ſlain;
" Truſt me, my love, I'll not complain,
" Not one weak drop my cheek ſhall ſtain,
" Ah, let thy fate of others claim
" I'll only murmur thy dear name—
'Twere vain for feeble words to tell
They only can conceive it well
The timid Muſe forbears to ſay
Nor paints the gallant deeds that day
On ſofter themes alone ſhe dwells,
Of friendſhip's woes ſhe ſad'ning tells,
Tho' long the beaming day was fled,
While night a deeper horror ſhed
The martial trump invades the ear,
No more the widow's ſhriek they hear,
The pangs thoſe dear-bought laurels yield,
Perchance not one that ſtrews the field
But leaves ſome heart to break.
To ALBERT's breaſt the faulſhion flew—
The drops that warm'd his heart, bedew
The Foe who aim'd the deadly dart,
Soft pity touch'd his yielding heart,
While round the Chief his arms he caſt,
And ſeem'd as if it mourn'd the paſt—
" Tho' nature heaves theſe feeble groans,
" Yet one dear care my heart ſtill owns,
" For YORK, a youth well known to fame
" Ah, tell him my expiring ſigh,
" To my deſpairing child to fly,
He ſpoke!—but oh, what mournful ſtrain
(Whom the dark ſhades of night conceal'd)
" Ah, fly (he cry'd) my touch profane!
His dying eyes he feebly rais'd,
On the pale youth they piteous gaz'd—
" And with the drops deſpair will ſhed,
" I'll go the tender maid to ſeek,
" To wipe the tear from her pale cheek,
" And at her feet to die."
And as the tender maid to ſeek
To wipe the tear from her pale cheek,
And hears in every paſſing breeze
Mean while the weeping maid, whoſe prayers
But yet had heard do more.
She ſaw her much-lov'd EDWIN near—
The ſight chill'd every falling tear—
" Eternal woes this heart muſt prove;
" Ah ſay, what ruthleſs arm, my love,
" Could not thy hand, my EDWIN, thine,
" For, ah, he was not only mine,
The pangs no ſtrains can tell;
From death he fondly hop'd a cure,
She flew—ſhe gave her ſorrows vent—
Her mournful voice, her moving plaint,
" Why wildly throbs each ſhiv'ring vein?
" Theſe pangs, my heart will break."
" Then trembling know thy father died,
" And know the guilt was mine."
" It is enough!"—with ſhort quick breath,
She ſpoke no more, but ſeem'd from death
But lo! a penſive, ſilent train
If good old ALBERT'S corſe were brought
A while her griefs to mourn.
But ah, all frantic at the ſight,
Then ſtarting wild with pale affright,
Trembling ſhe ruſh'd, and in her arms
But ſudden, paleneſs veil'd her charms
" To other worlds thy ſpirit flies,
" And mine this ſtroke ſhall free."
His hand the death-fraught weapon graſp'd,
When ſudden ſhe aroſe, and claſp'd
" I knew 'twas only found in death,
" To claſp him ſtill—'twas but a dream—
" Help yon wide wound to cloſe,
" From which a father's ſpirits ſtream,
" But ſee, from thee he ſhrinks! nor would
" Ah, tho' my EDWIN ſpilt thy blood,
" Yet once he lov'd thee much.
" My father, yet in pity ſtay!
" I ſee his white beard wave—
" And points to yon cold grave.
" E'en now, my love, I trembling hear
" I ſee, my love, the falling tear
" I feel within his aged arms
" I hear him ſpeak the fond alarms
" He's gone!—and here his aſhes ſleep;
" I do not heave a ſigh—
" His child a father does not weep,
" For, ah, my brain is dry!
" But come, together let us rove
" At the pale hour of night,
" When the moon glimm'ring thro' the grov
" We'll gather from the roſy bow'r
" We'll cull, my love, each op'ning flow'
" We'll thither from the diſtant dale,
" And plant a lily of the vale,
" We'll ſhun the glaring face of day,
" Thro' the dark wood we'll chearleſs ſtray,
" Some angel tells me 'tis a crime
" To hold thee to my heart.
" Is there no means, my EDWIN dear,
" And ſhould the torrent ceaſe to flow,
" Yet ſtill our hearts would bleed.
" Our hearts the ſecret would betray,
" Angels would come in dread array,
" Yet, EDWIN, if th' offence be thine
" But, oh, the guilt would all be mine,
" Farewell, my love!—for, ah, I faint:
" And ſee that hoary murder'd ſaint
" Poor, weak old man!—he comes, my love,
" To lead to heav'n the way;
" He knows not heaven will joyleſs prove,
" It is too much!" (he frantic cry'd)
The dying maid, who piteous ſigh'd—
He ſaw her dying eye-lids cloſe,
And yet no tear of anguiſh flows
For, ah, the fulneſs of deſpair,
He feels within his ſhivering veins
Her pallid corſe he feebly ſtrains—
No longer may their hapleſs lot
She wipes away the tears that blot
For heav'n in love diſſolves the ties
And diſtant far for ever flies
To bid the ſuff'rer's ſoul aſpire
To wake the pure, refin'd deſire,
